description: The Church of Saint Sava is a Serbian Orthodox church located on the Vračar plateau in Belgrade. It is the largest Orthodox church in Serbia, one of the largest Eastern Orthodox churches, and ranks among the largest churches in the world.

dimensions.length: 91 meters (298.5 ft) from east to west
dimensions.width: 81 meters (265.7 ft) from north to south
dimensions.dome_height: Additional 12 meters (39.4 ft) with gold-plated cross

architecture.exterior: Clad in white marble, featuring central dome and four smaller domes

interior.mosaics: World's largest mosaic decorations, surpassing even Hagia Sophia
interior.artists: 300 artists and craftspeople over four years

history.historical_significance: Location at Vračar was symbolically chosen due to the Ottoman burning of Sava's relics on a pyre in 1594/95 after a Serb uprising. The relics were publicly incinerated by the Ottomans on 27 April 1595.

construction_timeline.1935: Building began on May 10, 340 years after the burning of St. Sava's remains
construction_timeline.1941: Construction stopped during World War II and occupation of Yugoslavia. Foundation completed and walls erected to 7-11 meters
construction_timeline.1989: Massive 4,000-ton dome successfully hoisted into place

history.significance: Symbol of the rebirth of Serbian Orthodoxy and the enduring spirit of the Serbian people

visiting_information.guided_tours: 500-1000 Serbian dinars (€4-8), can be booked through official website
visiting_information.dress_code: Shoulders and knees must be covered. Men should remove hats inside.
visiting_information.photography: Permitted inside the church, but flash photography is restricted to protect mosaic work
visiting_information.best_time: Morning hours for fewer crowds and better lighting
visiting_information.recommended_duration: At least 2 hours to fully explore church and crypt
visiting_information.night_viewing: Spectacular to see the church lit up at night

unesco_recognition: The temple is a modern-day marvel representing one of the most significant Orthodox architectural achievements
interesting_facts: One of the largest Orthodox churches in the world
Construction took 85 years from start to full completion
Contains the world's largest mosaic decorations with 50 million pieces
Built on the site where Saint Sava's relics were burned by the Ottomans in 1595
The dome weighs 4,000 tons and was hoisted in one piece in 1989
